questions.text: Which of the following ligaments attaches the menisci to the tibial plateau?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ligaments connecting the menisci to the tibia are known as the coronary ligaments.

Ligaments related to menisci:

  • Coronary ligament
  • Meniscofemoral ligament
  • Transverse ligament

Coronary Ligaments:

  • These ligaments attach the periphery of both menisci to the periphery of the tibial condyles.
  • The coronary ligaments of the knee (also known as meniscotibial ligaments) are portions of the joint capsule that connect the inferior edges of the fibrocartilaginous menisci to the periphery of the tibial plateaus.
  • The coronary ligaments function to connect parts of the outside, inferior edges of the medial and lateral menisci to the joint capsule of the knee.

Meniscofemoral Ligaments:

  • These ligaments attach the posterior part of the lateral meniscus to the femur.
  • These are of two types:
    • Anterior meniscofemoral ligament (Ligament of Humphrey): Runs anterior to PCL.
    • Posterior meniscofemoral ligament (Ligament of Wrisberg ): Runs posterior to PCL.

Transverse Ligament:

It attaches the anterior edges of the medial and lateral menisci. (Option C ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

Arcuate ligament (Option B): The arcuate ligament is the ligament between the posterolateral femoral condyle to the fibular head. It covers the popliteus tendon.

Oblique ligament (Option D): The oblique popliteal ligament is the ligament from the semimembranous to the lateral femoral condyle, and it is derived from the semimembranous.

questions.text: A football player sustained a knee injury while playing. On examination, there is tenderness along the medial joint line. When the examiner applies pressure from the lateral side of the leg with the knee flexed at 30°, there is an opening up of the joint on the medial side. Which is the most likely ligament to be injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The test described indicates the valgus stress test, which specifically assesses the medial collateral ligament. Medial joint line tenderness and medial gapping confirm injury to the medial collateral ligament.

Medial collateral ligament:

  • The most commonly injured knee ligament is the MCL, followed by the ACL.
  • A valgus stress of the knee (from the lateral side) beyond the physiological limit can result in MCL injury.
  • Pain and swelling of the knee joint and with tenderness over the medial joint line and effusion, are commonly seen following injury.

Valgus stress test for MCL injury:

  • Done with knee at 30 degrees flexion with the patient lying supine. Examiner stabilises the thigh, and a valgus force is applied to the leg, and excessive medial gapping confirms MCL injury.
    • Opening up only at 30 degrees: Only MCL tear
    • Opening up at 0 to 30 degrees: MCL + ACL tear

Explanation of other options:

Anterior cruciate ligament (Option A): ACL is the most commonly operated knee ligament, as most of the MCL injuries are managed conservatively. ACL injuries usually result from twisting injuries to the knee. Anterior drawer test and Lachman test are used to assess ACL injury.

Lateral collateral ligament (Option C): LCL injury results from varus stressing of the knee beyond the physiological limit.

Posterior cruciate ligament (Option D): Classically injured by a posteriorly directed force on the tibia, such as dashboard injury, hyperflexion injury. PCL injury results in a positive posterior drawer test and Godfrey's sag sign.

questions.text: A 24-year-old athlete presents sustained twisting injury to the knee while practising. He reports hearing a popping sound at the time of injury, followed by swelling and inability to walk. The most sensitive test to confirm diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A twisting injury to the knee associated with pain, inability to bear weight and hearing a popping sound is usually associated with anterior cruciate ligament injury. The Lachman test is the most sensitive test to detect ACL injury.

Lachman test:

  • The most sensitive test for an Anterior cruciate ligament tear.
  • It is done with the knee flexed at 20 degrees, stabilising the distal femur with one hand and pulling forward on the proximal tibia with the other hand. With an intact ligament, minimal translation of the tibia occurs and a firm end point is felt; however, with a torn ACL, more translation is noted and the end point is soft or mushy.
  • Further, the Lachman test is more comfortable and painless for the patient in comparison to all the other tests, especially in an acute setting.

Test for ACL injury:

  • Lachman test
  • Anterior drawer test
  • Bounce home test
  • Pivot shift test

Explanation of other options:

McMurray test (Option A): Used for detecting a torn meniscus. The knee is flexed as far as possible; one hand steadies the joint, and the other rotates the leg medially and laterally while the knee is slowly extended. The test is repeated several times, with the knee stressed in valgus or varus, feeling and listening for the click. A positive test is helpful but not pathognomonic; a negative test does not exclude a tear.

Anterior drawer test (Option B): It is done with the knee at 90° of flexion and is not as sensitive as the Lachman test, but serves as an adjunct in the evaluation of ACL instability

Apley's grinding test (Option D): Apley's test is also used to detect meniscal tears. With the patient prone, the knee is flexed to 90 degrees and rotated while a compression force is applied; this reproduces the symptom if a meniscus is torn. Rotation is then repeated while the leg is pulled upwards with the surgeon's knee holding the thigh down; this, the distraction test, produces increased pain only if there is ligament damage.

Fig: Apley's grinding test

questions.text: A 17-year-old patient with a history of untreated tuberculosis of the knee presents with a deformed and painful joint. What is the characteristic tibial deformity seen in this case, known as the "triple deformity" of the knee?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Triple deformity of the knee consists of posterior subluxation of the tibia, external rotation of the tibia and flexion.

Triple deformity is classically seen in the late stages of TB of the knee joint. Rarely, rheumatoid arthritis can also produce similar deformity.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man complains of pain and swelling just below the patella. He gives a history of frequent kneeling during prayers. Which bursa is most likely inflamed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In an individual with a history of frequent kneeling and swelling located below the patella, the most likely bursa involved is the infrapatellar bursa. And likely diagnosis is infrapatellar bursitis.

Infrapatellar bursitis:

  • Also known as the clergyman's bursitis.
  • The swelling is below the patella and superficial to the patellar ligament, being more distally placed than prepatellar bursitis.
  • Treatment consists of firm bandaging, and kneeling is avoided; occasionally, aspiration is needed. In chronic cases, the lump is best excised.
  • Occasionally, the bursa is affected in gout.

Explanation of other options:

Prepatellar bursa (Option A): Prepatellar bursitis or the housemaid's knee presents with a fluctuant swelling confined to the front of the patella. This is a bursitis due to recurrent friction between skin and bone and is seen mainly in carpet layers, paving workers, floor cleaners and miners who do not use protective knee pads.

Olecranon bursa (Option C): Also known as the student's elbow, it results from repeated pressure or friction over the olecranon, causing the olecranon bursa to get enlarged and inflamed.

It usually occurs in students who write a lot while resting their elbows on the desk.

Ischial bursa (Option D): Ischial bursitis, also known as weaver's bottom, is the inflammation of the ischial bursa, which lies between the ischial tuberosity and the gluteus maximus. It is usually seen in individuals with a history of prolonged sitting on hard surfaces.

questions.text: A 20-year-old basketball player reports inability to extend the knee after sustaining a twisting injury. If a meniscal injury is suspected, which of the following is the most common mechanism of meniscus injuries?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common mechanism of injury in association with menisci is rotation and flexion.

Mechanism of injury to the Meniscus:

  • Damage to the meniscus is due to rotational forces directed to a flexed knee (as may occur with twisting sports).
  • A valgus force applied to a flexed knee with the foot planted and the femur rotated externally can result in a lateral meniscus tear.
  • A varus force applied to the flexed knee when the foot is planted and the femur rotated internally can result in a tear of the medial meniscus.

Symptoms of meniscus injury:

  • Knee pain and swelling
  • Another typical complaint is joint locking, when the patient is unable to straighten the leg fully. This can be accompanied by a clicking feeling.
  • Cooper's sign is a subjective symptom of pain in the affected knee when turning over in bed at night.t

The medial meniscus has less mobility than the lateral meniscus and is more susceptible to tearing when trapped between the femoral condyle and tibial plateau. Hence medial meniscus is the most commonly injured meniscus.

Tests for meniscus injury:

  • McMurrav test
  • Steinmann test
  • Apley grinding test
  • Apley's distraction test
  • Thesaly test
  • Ege's test

questions.text: A 24-year-old professional soccer player presents with discomfort and pain while walking, and an unstable knee joint following an injury during the match. The patient heard a popping sound at the time of injury. Physical examination reveals swelling of the knee joint, and the tibia can be moved excessively forward on the femur. Which of the following knee structures is most likely damaged?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The described symptoms and signs are characteristic of an anterior cruciate ligament injury or tear.

Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL):

  • Attachments of ACL:
    • Proximal attachment -Posterior part of the medial surface of the lateral femoral condyle
    • Distal attachment - Intercondylar area of tibia, passes upwards, backwards and laterally
  • It is intra-synovial.
  • ACL is most commonly injured with valgus, external rotation, hyperextension, deceleration, and rotational knee movements
  • The ACL injury rate is 4-6 times higher in females than in males in competitive sports.
  • The anterior cruciate ligament prevents anterior translation and rotation of the tibia on the femur.

Clinical features:

  • Immediate pain and an audible "pop".
  • Swelling of the knee is noted within a few hours (acute hemarthrosis).
  • The patient often states that the knee feels too unstable to continue playing and that weightbearing is difficult.
  • The most difficult action to perform in ACL injury is walking downhill
  • Typically, full knee extension is limited secondary to pain, effusion, hamstring spasm, and ACL stump impingement.
  • Flexion is often limited by effusion.

Tests for the anterior cruciate ligament:

  • Lachman test: Most sensitive
  • Anterior drawer test
  • Pivot shift test
  • Bounce home test

Explanation of other options:

Posterior cruciate ligament (Option A): Classically, PCL is injured by high velocity trauma with posterior dislocation of tibia on a flexed knee as in a 'dashboard impact' in a motor car. In a posterior Cruciate Ligament injury, climbing stairs is difficult.

Lateral collateral ligament (Option C): LCL injury results from varus stressing of the knee beyond the physiological limit.

Medial collateral ligament (Option D): The most commonly injured knee ligament is the MCL, followed by the ACL. A valgus stress of the knee (from the lateral side) beyond the physiological limit can result in MCL injury. Pain and swelling of the knee joint and with tenderness over the medial joint line and effusion, are commonly seen following injury.

choices.text: Anterior portion of the medial meniscus

questions.text: The patient presents to the OPD with pain and a feeling of buckling of the right knee. He gave a history of injury while playing hockey 3 months ago. On examination, the knee was unstable anteriorly in extension but was stable in 90 degrees of flexion. Probably injury involves:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The posterolateral fibres of the ACL are primarily responsible for stabilising the knee in extension; since the knee is unstable in extension but stable at 90° flexion, it indicates an isolated injury to the posterolateral bundle of the ACL.

  • The ACL ligament is the primary restraint to anterior tibial displacement, accounting for the resistance to the anterior drawer test when the knee is at flexion and neutral rotation.
  • ACL has 2 bundles-anteromedial and posterolateral.
  • The anteromedial fibres are tight in flexion, providing the primary restraint, whereas the posterolateral bulky portion of this ligament is tight in extension.
  • The posterolateral bundle also provides the principal resistance against hyperextension.
  • Therefore, in ACL tears:
    • A complete ACL tear will produce instability in both flexion and extension.
    • Anteromedial bundle tear will produce instability in flexion
    • Posterolateral bundle tear will produce instability in extension.

Explanation of other options:

ACL anteromedial fibre (Option A): The anteromedial bundle of the ACL is tight in flexion. Hence, if this fibre were injured, instability would be more noticeable in flexion.

Posterior cruciate ligament (Option C): It prevents posterior translation of the tibia, hence results in posterior instability, and instability would be worse in flexion, not just in extension.

Anterior portion of the medial meniscus (Option D): Medial meniscus injury typically causes joint line tenderness and locking.

questions.text: A football player, while playing, sustained a lateral blow to the knee joint. On examination, the unhappy triad of O'Donoghue was suspected. The trait involves injury to all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The unhappy triad of O'Donoghue involves a combined injury of the medial collateral ligament, the medial meniscus and the anterior cruciate ligament.

  • The unhappy triad was described by American orthopaedic surgeon D H O'Donoghue in 1950.
  • He described the simultaneous occurrence of a tear of the ACL, MCL and medial meniscus when a lateral force is applied to the knee while the foot is fixed to the ground.

choices.text: The medial meniscus is more mobile than the lateral
The lateral meniscus covers more tibial articular surface than the medial
The medial meniscus is more commonly injured than the lateral
Menisci are predominantly made up of Type I Collagen

questions.text: Which of the following statements about 'Menisci' is not true:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The medial meniscus is less mobile than the lateral meniscus. This is because the medial meniscus has an attachment onto the medial collateral ligament at the joint line.

Menisci of the knee:

  • Menisci are intrasynovial and intracapsular.
  • Menisci are made of fibrocartilage and act as shock absorbers between the femur and tibia.
  • The medial meniscus has less mobility than the lateral meniscus. This is because the medial meniscus has an attachment onto the medial collateral ligament at the joint line. This fixes the medial meniscus in its place.
  • The lateral meniscus has no such attachment on any ligament and is hence free to move.
  • The two menisci are connected anteriorly by the transverse ligament and are attached peripherally by the coronary ligaments.
  • The menisci move anteriorly in extension and posteriorly with flexion.

Explanation of other options:

The lateral meniscus covers more tibial articular surface than the medial (Option B): The Lateral meniscus is circular and covers more of the tibial articular surface compared to the medial meniscus, which is C-shaped.

The medial meniscus is more commonly injured than the lateral (Option C): Whenever there is a twisting injury to the knee, the lateral meniscus will move and escape injury; however, the medial meniscus, being less mobile, is more susceptible to tearing when trapped between the femoral condyle and tibial plateau. Hence medial meniscus is the most commonly injured meniscus.

Menisci are predominantly made up of Type I Collagen (Option D): Composed primarily of type I collagen. Collagen fibres are arranged in a variety of patterns:

  • Circumferentially to disperse hoop stresses, vertical mattress sutures capture these fibres.
  • Radially to resist longitudinal tearing
  • Randomly at the surface to disperse shear stresses caused by knee flexion

choices.text: Application of above-knee cast for 6 weeks
Icing, rest, compression and elevation for 2 weeks and then isometric and knee bending exercises

questions.text: A young cricket player comes to you with knee pain and an inability to extend it fully. He gives a history of twisting injury to his right knee when he collided with another player while fielding. His MRI shows a double PCL sign. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A double PCL sign on MRI is classically seen in a bucket-handle tear of a meniscus. The best treatment for an acute bucket-handle meniscal tear in young athletes is arthroscopic repair.

  • The inability to fully extend the knee suggests a locked knee and is characteristic of a bucket-handle meniscal tear.
  • Investigation of choice for knee joint injuries is
  • The best treatment for an acute bucket-handle meniscal tear in young athletes is arthroscopic repair.
  • However, if the meniscus injury is in the white- white zone, then a partial meniscectomy is done as the meniscus will not heal even if we do a repair because of the poor blood supply at the white -white zone.

Explanation of other options:

Application of above-knee cast for 6 weeks (Option B): Above-knee cylindrical cast is usually used for immobilisation in meniscal injuries before and after meniscal repair.

Icing, rest, compression and elevation for 2 weeks and then isometric and knee bending exercises (Option C): All these are supportive management for any injury. However, rehabilitation following meniscus repair should involve avoidance of knee flexion beyond 90 degrees.

Tension band wiring (Option D): Tension band wiring is never a choice for managing meniscal injuries. It is usually used for a two-part fracture of the patella.

choices.text: Varus/Valgus stress test in full flexion
Varus/Valgus stress test in full extension

questions.text: A 21-year-old hockey player is assessed for ligament injuries after sustaining an injury to his knee while playing. In this case, the structural integrity of collateral ligaments is best tested by;
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Opening of the knee joint to varus or valgus stress testing is done at 30 degrees of knee flexion to assess for collateral ligament injury.

  • Collateral ligaments are best tested by stress tests.
  • The varus stress test is for the lateral collateral ligament, while the valgus stress test is for the medial collateral ligament.
  • The examiner keeps one hand on the patient's flexed knee, which is positioned at 30 degrees, and uses the other hand to hold the leg, applying a varus or valgus stress to the knee.
  • Performing the tests at 30 degrees of knee flexion relaxes other structures in the knee, allowing for the specific isolation of the collateral ligaments for testing.
  • Opening to varus or valgus stress testing at only 30 degrees of knee flexion indicates an isolated collateral injury. Opening in full extension indicates a combined cruciate and collateral injury.

questions.text: Locking of the knee can be due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Locking of the knee can be physiological or pathological
  • Physiological locking references to internal rotation of the femur over a flexed/ grounded tibia in an extended knee.
  • Unlocking occurs when the popliteus rotates the femur externally, and the knee can then flex.
  • However, in orthopaedics, we usually talk of pathological locking, which refers to the restriction of the terminal few degrees of extension of the knee. This occurs when there is an intra-articular obstruction to the normal gliding of the tibial and femoral condyles.
  • Causes of pathological locking:
    • Torn meniscus (most common)
    • Loose bodies in the knee
    • Osteochondral fractures
    • Fractured osteophytes lying in the joint.
    • Foreign bodies

questions.text: A football player sustained a twisting injury to the knee while playing and presented to the ER with complaints of pain around the knee joint and inability to walk. The investigation of choice for ligament injuries of the knee is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Investigation of choice for knee ligament injury is MRI, as it will clearly show injuries of both the cruciates (intra-articular) and the collaterals (extra-articular). A twisting injury to the knee with inability to walk suggests a possible anterior cruciate ligament injury.

  • MRI is the gold standard imaging tool for the assessment of knee ligament injuries.
  • Increased availability has led to the widespread use of MRI to diagnose ligament, chondral and meniscal injuries, providing almost 100% sensitivity and over 90% accuracy.

MRI findings in ACL injury:

  • Discontinuity in ACL
  • Anterior translation of tibia
  • Empty notch sign
  • Buckling of PCL

Explanation of other options:

X-Rays (Option A): X-rays Plain X-rays may reveal associated fractures to the femoral condyles or tibial plateau in addition to small bony avulsions that can occur in conjunction with a ligament injury.

CT (Option B): CT is useful for the delineation of subtle fractures associated with ligament injuries and to determine exact fracture patterns. This is useful in planning reconstruction. CT is not useful for the assessment of ligamentous structures.

Arthroscopy (Option C): The investigation of choice for intra-articular knee structures, such as ACL, PCL, menisci and cartilage is diagnostic arthroscopy. This is because, when we put an arthroscope in the knee joint, we can visualise the intra-articular structures at 5 to 10 times magnification.

choices.text: Blow on the front of the upper tibia while the knee is flexed and the foot is plantar flexed
Blow on the back of the upper tibia while the knee is flexed and the foot is plantar flexed

questions.text: The most common mechanism of posterior cruciate ligament injury is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Posterior cruciate ligament injury results mostly from a direct blow to the anterior aspect of the knee, especially over the proximal tibia.

  • PCL tears are typically produced by external trauma, such as the classic "dashboard injury" resulting from a posteriorly directed force on the anterior aspect of the proximal tibia with the knee flexed and foot plantar flexed.
  • In athletics, the typical mechanism of isolated PCL tears is a direct blow to the anterior tibia or a fall onto the knee with the foot in a plantar flexed position.
  • Football, soccer, rugby and skiing are among the sports with the highest incidence of PCL tears.
  • Non-contact mechanisms, such as hyperflexion, are less common. (Option A ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

Blow on the back of the upper tibia while the knee is flexed and the foot is plantar flexed (Option D), Hyperextension non-contact injury (Option B): Both of these are mechanisms involved with anterior cruciate ligament injury, with the latter being less common. In ACL injuries, there is always a classic history of an axial-loading twisting injury on a slightly flexed knee. This commonly occurs when suddenly changing direction or landing and twisting from a jump in pivoting sports such as football, netball and rugby.

questions.text: Among the following, the intrarticular structures of the knee, all are intracapsular except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The collateral ligaments of the knee joint are both extracapsular and extrasynovial.

  • The cruciate ligaments of the knee joint are intracapsular and extrasynovial. (Option A ruled out)
  • They are extrasynovial because they don't derive their nutrition from synovial fluid, as they have their own blood supply.
  • Menisci derive their nutrition from synovial fluid; hence are intraarticular and intrasynovial. (Option B ruled out)
  • The anterior and posterior meniscofemoral ligamnets are intracapsular. (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

  • Extracapsular: MCL, LCL
  • Intracapsular:
    • Intrasynovial - Menisci
    • Extrasynovial - ACL, PCL

questions.text: Match the following clinical tests with the structures evaluated:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lachman test:

Best method for analysing anterior cruciate ligament injuries. Involves flexing the knee at 20-30 degrees and applying anterior force on the tibia. An excessive anterior translation is considered positive.

Dial test: The test involves externally rotating the tibia with the knee flexed at 30 degrees as the patient lies in the prone position. An increased external rotation indicates rotational instability due to the posterolateral corner complex injury.

Pivot shift test: The pivot test is used for assessing the anterolateral ligament. In anterolateral ligament injuries, there is a reduction of the subluxated lateral tibial plateau by the iliotibial band when the leg is moved from full extension to flexion.

Valgus stress test: The valgus stress test is done with the knee flexed at 0 and 30 degrees flexion. An increased opening up of the joint on the medial side, on applying valgus force, indicates MCL tear.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male sustained a fall while cycling and injured his knee. He heard a popping sound, and the knee swelled immediately. On examination, the Lachman test was positive. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Lachman test is positive in anterior cruciate ligament injuries and is the most sensitive test for assessing ACL injuries.

Lachman test:

  • Apply anterior force on tibia
  • If there is anterior translation, the test is +ve
  • It is the best clinical test as it can be done in the acute setting, takes the hamstring pull out of the equation and is the most sensitive test.

Anterior cruciate ligament:

  • Attachments:
    • Origin - Inner aspect of the lateral femoral condyle
    • Insertion - Intercondylar area of tibial plateau
  • It prevents anterior translation of the tibia.
  • Mechanism of ACL injury:
    • Hyperextension of the knee
    • Non-contact pivoting

Features of Acute ACL Tear:

  • Pain
  • Unable to weight bear
  • Pop sound at the time of injury
  • Immediate effusion of the knee

Features of a Chronic ACL Tear:

  • Feeling of instability
  • Difficulty going down stairs
  • Occasional pain

Clinical tests for ACL injury:

  • Anterior Drawer Test
  • Lachman test
  • Bounce home test
  • Pivot shift test

Explanation of other options:

Lateral meniscus tear (Option A), Medial meniscus tear (Option B): Meniscus injuries usually result from twisting injury to the knee during a fall, sports or RTA. The main complaint is of recurrent 'giving way' or 'a catch in the knee'. 'Locking' - i.e. the sudden inability to extend the knee fully - suggests a bucket-handle tear. The patient sometimes learns to 'unlock' the knee by bending it fully or by twisting it from side to side.

Fracture shaft of the tibia (Option C): These fractures usually result from twisting injuries and are commonly accompanied by fibular fractures. The commonest mechanisms are falls, sporting and transport accidents, with higher-energy mechanisms seen more commonly in younger patients.

choices.text: The main restraint in the posterior drawer test
It originates from the medial femoral condyle

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was brought to the ER following a road traffic accident. He complains of pain and swelling around the knee joint and recalls his knee hitting on dashboard. Which of the following is not true about the ligament injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The posterior cruciate ligament gets torn in hyperflexion injuries of the knee. And not hyperextension. Hyperextension injuries cause injury to the ACL.

Mechanisms of PCL injury:

  • RTA - Dashboard injury
  • Sports - Hyperflexion injury

Posterior cruciate ligament:

  • The cruciate ligaments of the knee joint are intracapsular and extrasynovial. (Option B ruled out)
  • Attachments:
    • Origin - Inner aspect of the medial femoral condyle (Option D ruled out)
    • Insertion- Posterior aspect of the tibial plateau
  • Function: Prevents posterior translation of the knee. This function of PCL is assessed with the posterior drawer test. In PCL injuries, there will be excessive posterior glide. (Option A ruled out)
  • Acute PCL tear is characterised by pain, swelling, and hemarthrosis
  • In chronic PCL tear, there will be difficulty climbing stairs and severe knee pain due to patellofemoral arthrosis
  • Test for PCL injuries:
    • Posterior Drawer test
    • Godfrey's Sag sign
    • Quadriceps active test

questions.text: A patient presents with knee pain and restricted movements following an RTA. The dial test was positive. Which among the following tests can also be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Knee injuries resulting in a positive dial test are suggestive of posterolateral corner complex injuries. Reverse pivot shift will also be positive in such injuries.

Posterolateral corner complex:

  • These are a group of ligaments in the posterolateral aspect of the knee that act as rotational stabilisers of the knee.
  • Tests for PLC injury:
    • Dial Test
    • External Rotation Recurvatum Test
    • Posterolateral Drawer Test
    • Reverse pivot shift

Dial test: During the test, the examiner externally rotates the tibia, with the knee flexed at 30 degrees, in a patient lying in the prone position. The test is positive if there is more external rotation.

Explanation of other options:

Thessaly test (Option A): Meniscal injuries can be detected with the Thessaly test. During the test, the patient stands on the affected leg with the knee flexed to 20 degrees and is asked to twist the body from side to side. A pain on the medial side points to a medial meniscus tear, and lateral side indicates a lateral meniscus tear.

Bounce home test (Option C): It is the clinical test for anterior cruciate ligament injuries. In this, the knee is suddenly extended from a flexed position and observed for the endpoint feel, which, if spongy or rubber, indicates ACL tear.

Quadriceps active test (Option D): Used for identifying posterior cruciate ligament injuries. The test involves observing for correction of posterior sag of the tibia when the quadriceps is contracted.

questions.text: A patient sustained a twisting injury to the knee 2 days ago. He developed pain and swelling of the knee the next day, and also complained of restriction of knee extension. On examination McMurray test is positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The McMurray test is positive in meniscus injuries and tests for the medial and lateral meniscus injuries.

Meniscus tears:

The medial meniscus is the most commonly meniscus to be injured meniscus, as it is less mobile than the lateral meniscus.

Medial meniscus tears are often associated with chronic ACL tears, while lateral meniscus tears are associated with acute ACL tears.

Symptoms:

  • Pain and delayed swelling knee
  • Clicks during knee movements
  • Locking of the knee - usually seen with bucket handle tears.

Signs:

  • Joint line tenderness - most common
  • Effusion
  • Palpable clicks on flexion and extension of the knee

Causes of meniscus tears:

  • Twisting injury of the knee
  • Fall/ sports Injury/ RTA
  • Degeneration in the meniscus
  • Osteoarthritis of the knee

Tests for meniscus tears:

  • McMurray test
  • Apley tests
  • Thessaly test
  • Ege's test

Explanation of other options:

Medial collateral ligament injury (Option A): MCL injuries result from valgus stress force to the knee during RTA, fall or sports injury. In such injuries, patients usually present with pain and swelling immediately. On examination, there will be tenderness over the MCL and a positive valgus stress test.

Anterior cruciate ligament injury (Option B): The common mechanism of injury involves hyperextension and non-contact pivoting. Patients typically complain of pain along with a popping sound heard during injury and inability to bear weight.

Intraarticular fracture (Option D): Axial loading with valgus or varus forces can result in intrarticular fracture of the tibia or femur along with involvement of the knee ligaments.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a knee injury after an RTA. He has severe swelling in his knee and a feeling of giving way of the knee while attempting to walk. His X-ray is given here. What injury will you suspect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The x-ray shows a capsular avulsion fracture of the lateral tibial condyle. Such fractures are called Segond fractures. Segond fractures are pathognomonic of an ACL injury.

If a patient presents with such a fracture, it is important to look beyond the fracture and get an MRI done to rule out an ACL tear and treat the patient accordingly.

Plain X-rays may reveal associated fractures to the femoral condyles or tibial plateau in addition to small bony avulsions that can occur in conjunction with a ligament injury. Bone may be avulsed from the:

  • Medial epicondyle of the femur at the origin of the MCL called as Pellegrini-Stieda lesion)
  • Tip of the fibula, probably from the LCL or a posterolateral corner injury
  • Tibial spine at the insertion of the ACL
  • Central portion of the posterior tibia at the insertion of the PCL (Option B ruled out)
  • Tibial plateau fractures can result in meniscal injuries (Option C, D ruled out)

Swelling of the knee immediately after the injury
A Feeling of knee buckling while attempting to walk

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with pain in the knee joint following an RTA resulting in him falling off from bike. On examination, there was translation of the tibia when an anterior force was applied with the knee flexed to 90 degrees. Which among the following is not a feature of the likely ligament injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anterior translation of the tibia with the knee flexed at 90 degrees indicates a positive drawer test, suggestive of anterior cruciate ligament injury. In patients with ACL tears, there is difficulty in climbing down stairs but not in climbing up stairs.

Features of acute ACL tear:

  • Pop sound at the time of injury (Option A ruled out)
  • Immediate effusion of the knee because of hemarthrosis (Option B ruled out)
  • Pain
  • Unable to weight bear

Features of chronic ACL tear:

  • Feeling of instability: Knee buckling refers to the feeling of giving away while walking or weight bearing and indicates knee joint instability. (Option C ruled out)
  • Difficulty going down stairs: This is because while coming down stairs, the tibia will be pulled anteriorly by gravity, and the tibia will translate anteriorly as there is no restraint from the ACL. This will result in a feeling of giving way and instability.
  • Occasional pain

questions.text: An athlete with an ACL injury following a non-contact pivoting injury was planned for ACL reconstruction. Which of the following tendon graft is commonly used for the procedure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Semitendinosus is the most commonly used tendon graft for ACL reconstruction.

Arthroscopic ACL reconstruction:

  • Initial management consists of physical therapy to restore motion. Immobilisation is avoided. Full ROM and good quadriceps control should be achieved before surgery.
  • During reconstruction, a tunnel is drilled in the femur and tibia, graft is placed and fixed in the tunnel to mimic the ACL.
  • Grafts commonly used are
    • Semitendinosus
    • Gracilis
    • Patellar tendon central 1/3rd

questions.text: A car driver was brought to the ER following an RTA with complaints of knee pain. While examining, the clinician noticed correction of posterior sag of the tibia when the quadriceps were contracted at 90-degree knee flexion as the extension of the knee was resisted at the ankle. Which ligament is being tested for the likely injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical test being performed is the quadriceps active test, used to rule out posterior cruciate ligament injuries.

Quadriceps active test:

The examiner resists knee extension by the ankle while supporting the thigh.

At 90° of knee flexion, a posterior sag caused by a damaged posterior cruciate ligament is corrected when the quadriceps contracts.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with knee pain after he injured his knee from a lateral blow to the joint. On examination, the orthopaedic surgeon performed a varus stress test, which was found positive. Which ligament was likely injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Varus stress test is used for identifying lateral collateral ligament tears.

  • Lateral collateral ligaments are mediolateral stabilisers of the knee joint and provide stabilisation against varus force.
  • LCL injuries result from varus stressing of the knee beyond the physiological limit.
  • Injuries cause pain nd swelling of the knee.
  • On examination, there will be tenderness over the LCL and effusion.

Varus Stress Test

  • Done with knee at 30 degrees flexion
  • The patient lies supine
  • The thigh is stabilised, and varus force is applied to the leg
  • If there is an opening up of the joint on the lateral side, it indicates an LCL tear

Explanation of other options:

Anterior cruciate ligament (Option A): ACL injuries result from hyperextension or twisting injuries. The Lachman test is the most sensitive test to detect an ACL tear.

Posterior cruciate ligament (Option B): The mechanism of injury in PCL tears is usually hyperflexion or a direct blow to the front of the knee, as in dashboard injury. A positive posterior drawer test is indicative of PCL injury.

Medial collateral ligament (Option C): Valgus stressing of the knee beyond the physiological limit leads to MCL injuries. The valgus stress test will show increased opening up of the joint on the medial side.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man complains of knee pain after a twisting injury while playing football. MRI revealed a tear in the avascular region of the meniscus. Which part of the meniscus is likely injured? Has the least vascularity?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

White white zone of the meniscus has the least vascularity and is most likely injured in this case.

Blood supply of the meniscus:

  • The blood supply to the meniscus is derived from the peri-capsular capillary plexus situated at the menisco-capsular junction.
  • The blood vessels from this plexus will enter the meniscus at the periphery and proceed towards the centre.
  • However, these blood vessels will reach roughly the middle of the meniscus and stop.

Meniscus has 3 zones based on vascularity:

  • Outer 1/3 (Red - red zone)- Good vascularity, good chances of healing; meniscal repair done, no neniscectomy
  • Middle 1/3 (Red - white zone)- little vascularity
  • Inner 1/3 (white - white zone)- very poor/ No vascularity, depends on synovial fluid for nutrition. Injury to this zone does not heal. Partial Meniscectomy done.
